title: Food Allergies and Your Elevator Speech

content: As the parent of a child with food allergies, I have found myself in many situations where I only have a couple of minutes to educate those that will be caring for my child with food allergies. This is in addition to any other communication that has already been shared via email or other means.
Living a whole, full life with food allergies

It is not uncommon for a child to participate in a team sport, visit a friend’s house, attend a church Sunday school class, or take part in another situation in which they will be out of your care for a short time. You will need to educate the adults in charge with some basic information to help keep your child safe. This may include but is not limited to:
Sharing information with organizations and businesses about food allergy care

content_blocks.text: As the parent of a child with food allergies, I have found myself in many situations where I only have a couple of minutes to educate those that will be caring for my child with food allergies. This is in addition to any other communication that has already been shared via email or other means.
Living a whole, full life with food allergies

It is not uncommon for a child to participate in a team sport, visit a friend’s house, attend a church Sunday school class, or take part in another situation in which they will be out of your care for a short time. You will need to educate the adults in charge with some basic information to help keep your child safe. This may include but is not limited to:
Sharing information with organizations and businesses about food allergy care

content: While most people, organizations, and businesses have the best of intentions when collecting this information, it is uncertain how familiar each person is with what you have shared. There’s also the question of how well-versed the individual or organization is in food allergy education and awareness when it comes to pre-existing knowledge and experience. Combine that with the fire-hydrant flow of information that we know first-hand as caregivers or parents of children with food allergies, and it is quite the task to relay this very important arsenal of information.

I try to send or relay the information in portions. Depending on the situation or individual, I will send some of the more general information upon my first interaction. This may include the Food Allergy Action Plan in PDF via email or printed and given in person. Additionally, what allergens he is allergic to and stressing that it is a life-threatening anaphylactic food allergy.

From there, after some time has passed, I will ask if they need additional information on self-carrying medication, emergency contact information, how to administer epinephrine, or other resources. This typically happens with larger or more professionally structured organizations, such as school or Scouting, for example. I have found it helpful to send a YouTube video for a visual on how to administer epinephrine and have received great feedback that this has been most helpful.

sections.heading: The 60-second elevator speech
content: Contingent on the type of activity, I would reach out the day prior to the day of the event or activity. This gives them one more opportunity to get information, ask questions, and prepare accordingly. I share my 60-second elevator speech. While I have done my best up to this point to give information in a way that is appropriate for the event, while also not overwhelming in small tidbits, I rehearse a brief education and awareness speech.
If you have 1 minute to relay the most important things about caring for your child, what words or messages would you impart to someone? For me, it includes:
bullets: Reiterating that my child has a life-threatening reaction to food(s), known as anaphylaxis, and that should he have a reaction, they need to not hesitate and epi first, and epi fast
Listing the food(s) that my child is allergic to, as well as if they are not in the top nine food allergens, what they may be disguised as in a food label
Letting them know that he cannot eat anything from a buffet, homemade, or otherwise not store-bought with a label that has been read and shows it does not include his allergen
What signs and symptoms to look for
Then I show them the epinephrine auto-injectors, where he keeps them on his person, and give a brief how-to-administer.

This gives them one more opportunity to get information, ask questions, and prepare accordingly. I share my 60-second elevator speech. If you have 1 minute to relay the most important things about caring for your child, what words or messages would you impart to someone? For me, it includes:
associated_bullets: Reiterating that my child has a life-threatening reaction to food(s), known as anaphylaxis, and that should he have a reaction, they need to not hesitate and epi first, and epi fast
Listing the food(s) that my child is allergic to, as well as if they are not in the top nine food allergens, what they may be disguised as in a food label
Letting them know that he cannot eat anything from a buffet, homemade, or otherwise not store-bought with a label that has been read and shows it does not include his allergen
What signs and symptoms to look for
Then I show them the epinephrine auto-injectors, where he keeps them on his person, and give a brief how-to-administer.

content: To easily remember this, you may then turn these talking points for your 60-second elevator speech into one-word prompts, to keep your messaging on-point. Doing so, based on the above, may look something like this:

Once I complete my 60-second elevator speech, I thank them so much for having my son over, and to not hesitate to contact me with any questions. I emphasize that there is no question too big or too small. I’d rather them ask than to guess.

It’s important to remember that this can be overwhelming to others that do not live this lifestyle of caring for someone with a life-threatening condition. Consider the main points you want them to remember and try to be as concise yet as informative as possible.

sections.heading: Teach and prepare your child for the unexpected
content: One other step I take is to teach and prepare my child. They become well-versed in the information that is shared in my 60-second elevator speech so that they can employ these safety measures firsthand, but also so that they can learn to be their own advocates. Additionally, I prepare them to be able to say no thank you to a food, read a label, and bring their own safe snacks.

content_blocks.text: One other step I take is to teach and prepare my child. Additionally, I prepare them to be able to say no thank you to a food, read a label, and bring their own safe snacks.

sections.heading: Set the stage for a life of possibilities with food allergies
content: While this is not all-encompassing of all measures that can be taken when it comes to advocacy, education, and awareness of those with food allergies, it is a valuable tool to have when navigating life with food allergies. Sometimes, there is not an ideal flow of information, or process, and this 60-second elevator speech has afforded my son with many opportunities to partake in a whole, full life with food allergies. Instead of thinking that many activities are off-limits, we approach it with an “I can” attitude, and then figure out how to safely navigate with a little preparedness and communication going a long way! Think of it as the CliffsNotes version of education, advocacy, and awareness communicated to those caring for your child.
